While Thailand and the Philippines have data retention requirements across various sectors, as does India which has extensive data localization requirements affecting multiple sectors, including financial services, insurance, and corporate entities. Sri Lanka primarily focuses these obligations on the banking sector. Data localization is less developed in the Philippines and Sri Lanka, with the latter\'s requirements largely limited to financial institutions. Nepal\'s approach is more tentative, indicated through a non-legislative resolution. Data transfer obligations that may indirectly support data localization are seen in Thailand, the Philippines, and Sri Lanka.

##### India

Data localization in India involves a set of legal frameworks that mandate the storage, processing, and management of certain categories of data within the country. The Official Secrets Act, 1923, restricts data flow by prohibiting the communication of sensitive information, emphasizing the importance of national security. The Act\'s broad powers allow the government to control the dissemination of information that might affect state interests, fostering a culture of secrecy.

The Reserve Bank of India\'s (RBI) Notification on Storage of Payment Data mandates that all payment-related data must be stored within India, ensuring tighter regulatory oversight and data security. Similarly, the Companies (Accounts) Rules, 2014, and the amended Companies Act, 2013, require that financial records and other relevant documents are accessible within India, even if they are maintained electronically. The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI) also requires insurers to store policy-related records in domestic data centers. These rules limit the cross-border transfer of sensitive financial and corporate data, reinforcing India\'s jurisdiction over such information.

Additional regulations include the Cyber Security Directions, 2022, issued by CERT-In, which impose data localization requirements on digital personal data, prohibit anonymous VPN usage, and require identity verification of data users. The Unified Access License by the Department of Telecommunications restricts the transfer of customer information outside India and imposes surveillance obligations on service providers. Similarly, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) framework mandates that data related to SEBI-regulated entities, including financial institutions using Software as a Service (SaaS), must be stored within India.

##### Indonesia

PDP Law distinguishes the previously known electronic system provider, into Personal Data Controllers ("Data Controllers") and Personal Data Processors ("Data Processors"). The Data Controllers determine the purpose and control the processing of personal data, while the Data Processors act on behalf of the Data Controllers to perform the processing of personal data. The Data Controllers must ensure that there is adequate and binding protection, or at the very least, consent must be given from the personal data subjects. PDP Law restricts any person to: (a) unlawfully obtain/collect personal data that does not belong to them, with the intention to benefit themselves or other persons which will be disadvantageous to the Personal Data Subject; (b) unlawfully disclose and use personal data that does not belong to them; (c) create false personal data with the intention to benefit themselves or other persons which may result in the loss of other persons.

##### Nepal

There are provisions in the RTI (Right to Information) Act for classification of information [@RightInformationAct2007][^21] and keeping information confidential for a maximum period of 30 years [@RightInformationAct2007].[^22] However, it is not explicitly stated whether these provisions apply specifically to personal data for security purposes. While the laws of Nepal are silent on data residency or data localization, there is a cabinet decision which states that all the data and information technology of the government of Nepal shall be stored and managed in the Government Integrated Data Center along with the Disaster Recovery Center located in Kathmandu and Hetauda respectively.[^23] Although the Cabinet decision also does not explicitly talk about data localization, while interviewing various government personnel it has come to light that the intent of the government of Nepal is to store data collected in Nepal within the territory of Nepal.

##### Pakistan

Pakistan's approach to data localization has been complex, with multiple laws, regulations, and policies developed over the years. Localization was first alluded to in the Pakistan Broadband Policy (2004), by referring to \"locally located content\" with the motivation to host websites locally for reducing reliance on international bandwidth. However, subsequent references have been more explicit. For example, the Pakistan Cloud First Policy prescribes that data localization is a rule and transborder data flow is an exception subject to permission. This sentiment is echoed in the current draft of the Draft Personal Data Protection (PDP) Bill, which adds a special category of critical personal data, in addition to the usual personal data and sensitive personal data to justify the data localization ambition.

There are also data localizations requirements in other laws and policies in Pakistan:

Pakistan Broadband Policy refers to "locally located content" with the motivation to host websites locally.

Pakistan Cloud First Policy requires that whenever there are legitimate use-cases requiring cross-border data flows, then the relevant stakeholders may consult with the Cloud Office established under the policy, to ensure appropriate security standards and controls are in place for such data flows.

Email and Internet Policy for the Federal government says that government entities shall only use government data centers. If that is not available, services of local ISPs will only be used.

Removal and Blocking of Unlawful Online Content (Procedure, Oversight and Safeguards) Rules, 2021 prescribes that a significant social media company must register with PTA, establish an office in Pakistan, appoint an authorized compliance officer, and a dedicated grievance officer, both based in Pakistan and comply with the user data privacy and data localization requirements.

Cyber Security Strategy for Telecom Sector 2023-2028 developed under Pakistan Telecommunication (Re-organization) Act, 1996 requires Critical Telecom Data (CTD) to reside within the geographical boundaries of Pakistan. However, the localization requirement is only limited to Personal Identifiable Information (PII) and CTD.

Draft Personal Data Protection (PDP) Bill adds a special category of critical personal data to the localization requirement.

##### Philippines

The 2012 Data Privacy Act requires that personal information must be retained only for as long as necessary for the fulfilment of the purposes for which the data was obtained or for the establishment, exercise, or defense of legal claims, or for legitimate purposes or as provided by law. The Philippines has no law governing data localization, although the Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT) has prescribed the Philippine Government's Cloud First Policy, which includes a provision on data residency. The residency restrictions generally do not apply to government data stored or processed in the cloud, provided that appropriate controls or security measures are present. However, sensitive, above-sensitive, and highly sensitive government data may be subject to some residency restrictions [@AmendmentsDepartmentCircular2020].[^24]

##### Sri Lanka

Section 9 of the Personal Data Protection Act mandates that personal details should only be maintained for a period that is necessary or required for specific purpose. As for data localization, the Regulatory Framework on Technology Risk Management and Resilience for Licensed Banks and Banking Direction No. 16 of 2021 mandates that 'Domestic Systematically Important Banks' must have Critical Information systems in place. For such systems (including those used for Know Your Customer or KYC), disaster recovery arrangements must be located locally [@srilankaBankingActDirections2021]. Additionally, third-party service providers such as cloud servers located outside Sri Lanka must be approved by the licensed Bank\'s Board of Directors and comply with certain conditions.

##### Thailand

There are two main laws which impose regulations on data retention. The first is the Computer-Related Crime Act (No.2) B.E.2560 (2017), and the second is the Personal Data Protection Act B.E.2562 (2019). The former requires service providers to retain traffic data for at least 90 days from the date the data entered the computer system. In addition, it must store the user's data, for identification purposes, for at least 90 days after the expiration date of a service [@ComputerRelatedCrimeAct2007].[^25] The Personal Data Protection Act makes it compulsory for data controllers to specify the period of data retention (in accordance with the purpose of the personal data collection) and inform data subjects prior or during the consent request [@PersonalDataProtection2019].[^26] In addition, data controllers have a duty to delete or destroy the personal data after the data retention has expired [@PersonalDataProtection2019].[^27]

Every country studied has exemptions in place which restrict access to information on the grounds similar to national security, public order, privacy, etc. either by incorporating such restrictions in the Constitution itself or by introducing them in statutes or legislations.

##### India

In India, the Right to Information (RTI) Act includes several exceptions to the disclosure of information. Information may be withheld if its release could harm national security, strategic interests, or international relations, or if it has been restricted by a court order. Additionally, details that might breach parliamentary privilege, affect commercial or intellectual property interests, or endanger individuals are exempt. Confidential information from foreign governments, ongoing investigations, and personal data are also protected.

Certain organizations, such as intelligence and security agencies, are exempt from the RTI Act, though information related to allegations of corruption or human rights violations must be disclosed with appropriate approvals.

Section 5 of the Official Secrets Act, 1923 also restricts access by criminalizing the wrongful communication of classified information. This includes any data related to prohibited areas or matters that could impact national security or foreign relations. The Act penalizes the unauthorized sharing or misuse of such information, as well as the failure to secure or properly manage classified documents. In case of any conflict between the laws, the RTI Act takes precedence due to Section 22 of the Act, which explicitly states that "The provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in the Official Secrets Act, 1923..."

##### Indonesia

The RTI Law adopts a "right" of public agencies to refuse access to public information. Nevertheless, the institution is required to explain all exemptions restrictively and the information may not stay restricted permanently. Information that should be exempt from public access relates to law enforcement, intellectual property, fair competition practices, defense and security of the state, natural wealth, national economic security, diplomatic relations, personal secrets, and similar.

The rights of Personal Data Subjects excluded for the interests of national defense and security; the interests of the law enforcement process; the public interest in the framework of state administration; the interests of supervision of the financial services sector, monetary, payment systems, and the stability of the financial system carried out in the framework of state administration; or the interests of statistics and scientific research.

##### Nepal

The explicit right to communication provision in the Constitution of Nepal can be restricted on some grounds, such as sovereignty, territorial integrity, harmony between communities, public morals, contempt and sedition. The Telecommunication Act, 2053 (1997) gives special power to the Government of Nepal where it can control or stop transmission of information in the state of emergency or national security in the country [@nepalTelecommunicationsAct1993].[^28] The Press and Publications Act, 2048 (1991) provides for restriction [@PressPublicationAct1991][^29] and prohibition [@PressPublicationAct1991][^30] on publication on any matter which undermines the sovereignty and integrity of Nepal or, disrupts security, peace and order or, creates enmity among the people of various castes, tribes, religions, classes, region, communities and spreading communal disharmony or, hurting decency, morals and social honor of the people PressPublicationAct1991.[^31] It also provides for the restriction on imports of foreign publications along the same lines [@PressPublicationAct1991].[^32]

##### Pakistan

The Right of Access to Information Act in Pakistan contains several exceptions that restrict the right to access information including public interest, privacy, confidentiality, international relations, prevention of an offence, etc. The Federal Government has also framed the Removal and Blocking of Unlawful Online Content (Procedure, Oversight and Safeguards) Rules, 2021, under the Telecom Act which gives the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority the power of removal or blocking access to online content in the interest of glory of Islam, security of Pakistan, public order, decency and morality and security or defense of Pakistan. The Pakistan Electronic Media Regulatory Authority (PEMRA) occasionally halts broadcasts and closes media outlets under Section 30 of the Pakistan Electronic Media Regulatory Authority Ordinance 2002 depriving viewers of necessary access to information and data.

##### Philippines

The Memorandum from the Executive Secretary dated 24 November 2016, also known as the Inventory of Exceptions to Executive Order No. 2 (S. 2016), lists several restrictions on the right to access information. These include the doctrine of executive privilege, information related to national security, defense, or international relations, law enforcement and protection of public and personal safety, confidentiality, and privacy [@InventoryExceptionsExecutive2016]. The 1997 Indigenous People's Rights Act, which grants the Indigenous peoples of Philippines ownership and control over their cultural and intellectual property, including their genetic data and biological resources within ancestral lands and domains, requires the free and prior informed consent of the indigenous communities before such data can be accessed [@IndigenousPeoplesRights1997]. The Data Privacy Act of 2012 along with a number of other sectoral laws such as the 2004 Violence Against Women and Their Children Act, the 2022 Anti-Online Sexual Abuse and Exploitation of Children and Anti-Child Sexual Abuse and Exploitation Materials Act, etc. also impose restrictions on the processing and sharing of personal data, both by government agencies and private entities.

##### Sri Lanka

Sri Lanka has restrictions on the constitutional right to access information such as national security, territorial integrity or public safety, for the prevention of disorder or crime, for the protection of health or morals and of the reputation or the rights of others, privacy, prevention of contempt of court, protection of parliamentary privilege, for preventing the disclosure of information communicated in confidence, or for maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary [@ConstitutionSL2023].[^33] Sri Lanka Telecommunications Act No. 25 of 1991 (as amended) ("SLTA"), Computer Crime Act No. 24 of 2007, International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights Act No. 56 of 2007, the Prevention of Terrorism Act of 1979 and Public Security Ordinance No 25 of 1947 (in the event of an emergency being declared). The Online Safety Act No 9 of 2024 with its broad provisions seeks to regulate disinformation online, amongst others [@OnlineSafetyAct2024a].

##### Thailand

Under the 2017 Thai Constitution, the constitutional rights and liberties may be restricted or limited by law for the protection of national security and the preservation of public order. The Constitutional obligation to disclose public information under Section 59 of the Constitution does not apply to information relating to national security and state secrets. Additionally, Section 32 of the 2017 Thai Constitution guarantees the right to privacy and the protection of personal data, and the Personal Data Protection Act B.E.2562 (2019) is consistent with this protection. The Computer-Related Crime Act (No.2) B.E.2560 (2017) also provides mechanisms for restricting access to information deemed to constitute national security or terrorism-related offences, while the Rule on Maintenance of Official Secrets B.E. 2544 (2001) lays down a practical framework on how to categorize and treat different types of "official secrets" (which are categorized into confidential, secret and top-secret information).

All the countries have an exception to their data security framework for law enforcement in some form or the other. This exception is usually crafted in broad terms but, generally speaking, deals with the investigation and prevention of crimes. While the Philippines and Nepal give the power to pass such orders to the judicial system, etc. the courts, in Sri Lanka, Pakistan and India this power is exercised by the law enforcement agencies themselves.

##### India

Various laws have provisions for surveillance and interception for law enforcement purposes, including Sections 69 and 69B of the Information Technology Act, 2000, and Section 20 of the Telecommunications Act, 2023 (replacing Section 5 of the Indian Telegraph Act, 1885). These provisions, along with the rules made thereunder, allow for interception of electronic communications and for compelled decryption of communications. Section 26 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898, empowers the central and state government to intercept postal articles.

Section 94 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 (which replaced the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973) allows any court in India or any officer in charge of a police station to summon a person to produce any document or any other thing that is necessary for the purposes of any investigation, inquiry, trial or other proceeding. Section 95 allows for the interception of a document, parcel or thing in the possession of a postal or telegraph authority. Surveillance procedures are also covered under various states' Police Acts and the national Model Police Manual.

Section 17(1)(c) of the Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023 exempts the application of the much of the law when "personal data is processed in the interest of prevention, detection, investigation or prosecution of any offence or contravention of any law for the time being in force in India". Section 17(2)(a) provides a wide-ranging exemption for "such instrumentality of the State as the Central Government may notify, in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, maintenance of public order or preventing incitement to any cognizable offence relating to any of these." The government will presumably notify intelligence agencies under this provision.

##### Indonesia

The PDP Law exception of protection data personal can be limited or exempted subject to the implementation of laws and regulations for the following reasons:

a.  national defense and security interests;

b.  law enforcement process interests;

c.  public interest, for the purpose of state administration;

d.  the interests of supervision of the financial services sector, monetary, payment systems, and financial systems stability carried out in the context of state administration; or

e.  general statistical and scientific research interests.

All exemptions except for the one relating to the "natural wealth" of Indonesia are subject to a harm test. Equally, there is a mandatory public interest override applicable to all exemptions; should revealing the information serve a "larger interest," the otherwise protected information shall be released to the public [@PublicInformationDisclosure2008].[^34] The RTI Act provides for internal and external appeal options. Internally, the appeal is with the supervisor of the information officer. An external administrative appeal is possible with the Information Committee, an independent institution competent for overseeing the implementation of the RTI Act. It consists of the central, provincial, and, if required, district/municipal Information Committees [@PublicInformationDisclosure2008].[^35]

##### Nepal

There is no provision or facility for internet surveillance in Nepal. There are no resources available for the surveillance on the customer browsing and tracking the web history of each citizen. However, if a court orders an internet service provider or telecommunication service provider to record the data of any individual and make available such data, only after the date of such an order can the service provider record and store such data. But through our interviews, it came to light that even if the court orders for surveillance of any individual, the service providers face problems while retrieving such data or most of the service providers do not have the resources for the same. Therefore, the order of the court becomes impractical or ineffective due to the limitations of the service providers.

##### Pakistan

Under Section 54 of the Pakistan Telecommunication (Re-organization) Act, 1996, the Federal Government has the power to authorize any person to intercept calls and messages violating the privacy of individuals in the national interest or on the mere apprehension of an offence. Under the same section, in case of proclamation of emergency, hostilities or war, the Federal Government can take over or suspend the operations or services of any service provider thereby depriving their customers from using the telecommunication networks. Under Sections 31 and 35 of the Prevention of Electronic Crimes Act, 2016, the authorized officers have sweeping powers to require any person to provide any data in decrypted form, if the authorized officer is satisfied that it is required for an investigation and there is risk of it being modified, lost or destroyed.

##### Philippines

The Bill of Rights of the Philippine Constitution specifically guarantees that "the privacy of communication and correspondence shall be inviolable, except upon lawful order of the court, or when public safety or order requires otherwise, as prescribed by law." In connection with cybercrime offences, the interception of computer data by law enforcement authorities may be authorized by the trial courts by virtue of a warrant to intercept computer data that allows authorities to listen, record, monitor or surveil the content of communications including the procuring of content of computer data through access and use of a computer system [@RuleCybercrimeWarrants2018]. The application for the warrant must establish, among others, the existence of a probable cybercrime offence, and the communication or computer data that is sought to be intercepted.

In connection with suspected terrorists or members of terrorist organizations, the 2020 Anti-Terrorism Act allows for the Court of Appeals to issue an order authorizing law enforcement or military to secretly wiretap, listen to, or intercept any private communications between such suspects [@AntiTerrorismAct2020]. The order may be issued by the Court of Appeals upon determination that there is probable cause that any of the crimes defined under the Anti-Terrorism Act has been, is being, or is about to be committed.

##### Sri Lanka

Sri Lanka, whilst prohibiting unauthorized/unlawful interception by several statutes, does not have a specific legislation/policy addressing lawful interception of telecommunication and electronic communication content. However, in certain circumstances interception of data, may be permitted:

**(1)** **Sri Lanka Telecommunications Act:** Section 69 of the Act states that if, due to any public emergency or in the interest of public safety and tranquility, it is expedient or necessary that the transmission and reception of messages by telecommunications should be prohibited or be subject to supervision and control, the Minister may issue a direction either (i) generally and published in the Gazette or (ii) specifically in writing in respect of any telecommunications service provided in any place in Sri Lanka, the Minister may also prescribe the conditions and restrictions subject to which messages may be transmitted or received and make such provision as he may deem necessary for the interception or the censoring of all or any specified class or description of messages (Section 69(b)).[^36]

**(2)** **Public Security Ordinance**: Emergency Regulations, when made, override all laws of the country except the Constitution. Accordingly, in an instance where the President declares a state of emergency, the President in his sole discretion may set out any regulation that he deems fit and this may include regulation to intercept, retain and/or disclose any telecommunication or electronic communication content.

**(3) Computer Crime Act**: Under Section 18 of the Act, a police officer or expert for the purposes of investigation may intercept communication subject to a warrant being issued by a Magistrate. The requirement of a warrant for interception can be waived on grounds of urgency; evidence being lost / destroyed; and requirement of confidentiality.

##### Thailand

There are certain pieces of legislation that allow authorities to conduct surveillance and intercept information and data from individuals. Most of these laws are related to the prevention and suppression of crimes. Each provides different grounds for requesting a warrant for surveillance and interception. These include the National Intelligence Act B.E. 2562 (2019), the Narcotics Control Act B.E. 2519 (1976), the Anti-Money Laundering Act B.E. 2542 (1999), the Special Case Investigation Act B.E. 2547 (2004), and the Anti-Participation in Transnational Organized Crime Act B.E. 2556 (2013). Normally, the power to consider and grant a warrant lies with the court.

### Privacy and data protection

#### Cross-border transfers

**1. Does the privacy law have any restriction on cross border data transfers?**

| Nepal                             | - None                                                                                                           |
+-----------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Pakistan                          | - Draft Personal Data Protection Bill                                                                            |
